title-group.article-title: Pelagic ecosystem responses to changes in seawater conditions during the Middle Pleistocene Transition in the Eastern Mediterranean

abstract.p: We present a multiproxy, ecosystem-level assessment of paleoenvironmental change and its impacts on marine organisms in the Eastern Mediterranean during the Middle Pleistocene Transition, between 923 and 756 kyr B.P. (marine isotope stages MIS 23–18). This study combines analyses of organic biomarkers; organic matter content; carbon and oxygen stable isotopes on bulk sediment, surface-dwelling, deep-dwelling planktonic and benthic foraminifera, ostracods and fish otoliths; as well as foraminiferal, ostracod and sponge abundance estimates, with a statistical assessment of paleoenvironmental regime shifts and estimation of fish distribution depths in the past. Our results show that temperature and productivity played the most important role in driving ecosystem changes in the study area at different times: temperature was the primary driver during MIS 21 interglacial, whereas productivity became a dominant factor in MIS 19 interglacial. In addition, the responses of organisms throughout the water column varied. Both interglacials yielded relatively higher plankton and benthos biomasses. However, for fishes, the responses differed. The abrupt global warming that occurred in early MIS 21, which was also captured by our record, probably led to a reduction in diel vertical migration by mesopelagic fishes and consequently to the efficiency of the biological carbon pump. In contrast, increased productivity across trophic levels is attested for MIS 19 that subsequently dropped in MIS 18, affecting foraminifera, ostracod and sponge biomasses, but not inhibiting fish diel vertical migration. Therefore, we conclude that carbon sequestration during MIS 19 was likely enhanced.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The Middle Pleistocene Transition (MPT; 1.25–0.7 Ma) was an important period in recent climate evolution, marking the shift from the Pliocene symmetrical 41-ky to the modern 100-ky frequency, higher-amplitude, asymmetrical climate cycles (Head and Gibbard, 2015). This shift was associated with the expansion of the Northern Hemisphere ice sheets (Ao et al., 2023; Berends et al., 2021; Clark et al., 2006; Elderfield et al., 2012) triggered by Antarctic ice-sheet growth (An et al., 2024) and led to major changes in the marine (Agiadi et al., 2011) and terrestrial biota (Cirilli et al., 2023), including a severe demographic crisis in human populations (Hu et al., 2023; Margari et al., 2023).

The conditions in the Mediterranean have been the topic of numerous studies because it was a hotspot of ancient human population change associated with the climate changes in the MPT (Margari et al., 2023). Sea surface temperature (SST) and primary productivity changes have been reconstructed with high temporal resolution in the Western and Central Mediterranean (Marino et al., 2020, 2022; Martínez-Dios et al., 2021; Nomade et al., 2019; Quivelli et al., 2021) and the southwestern Iberian margin (Girone et al., 2023; Rodrigues et al., 2017; Sánchez Goñi et al., 2023), providing up to millennial-scale paleoclimate reconstructions with even records of short-term extreme cooling events attributed to the reduction of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation. Very few studies have been conducted in the Eastern Mediterranean however (Eichner et al., 2024; Incarbona et al., 2022; Quillévéré et al., 2016, 2019). Particularly, a gap in knowledge remains regarding seawater conditions (i.e., temperature, thermal gradient, and salinity) and productivity in the Eastern Mediterranean during the MPT. The Eastern Mediterranean is currently affected by particularly much drier and ∼4 °C warmer climatic conditions than the Western (Minnett et al., 2019). In addition, the riverine influx counterbalances, only up to a point, the negative water budget of the region promoted by extreme evaporation, and therefore much saltier sea surface conditions (> 39) prevail there than in the Western Mediterranean (∼36.5). Such warmer and saltier conditions were last observed in the area in the Late Miocene (Besiou et al., 2024; Kontakiotis et al., 2022; Vasiliev et al., 2019) and it becomes intuitive that seawater conditions during the MPT may have also been very different from those in the Western Mediterranean.

Climate change affects the size and metabolism of marine organisms (Daufresne et al., 2009; Ohlberger, 2013), and consequently marine ecosystem structure and function (Hildrew et al., 2007). Although some aspects of the response of marine organisms to the paleoclimatic changes that occurred in the Mediterranean during the MPT have been studied so far, such as the composition of the calcareous nannoplankton (Marino et al., 2008, 2020), planktonic foraminifera (Quillévéré et al., 2019; Quivelli et al., 2021), and fish communities (Agiadi et al., 2011, 2018; Girone and Varola, 2001), as well as the body size of bivalves (Porz et al., 2024) and fishes (Agiadi et al., 2023), many questions remain about secondary production by zooplankton and zoobenthos, and the metabolic response of higher-trophic–level organisms.

Foraminifera are very sensitive to parameters of ambient seawater, such as food supply, light intensity, and sea temperature, which control community composition and pelagic biomass production (Gooday and Jorissen, 2012; Schiebel et al., 2018). In the case of the MPT, no consistent global patterns have been found, and productivity changes have been related mostly to regional changes in nutrient supply through variations in the hydrographic regime (Diester-Haass et al., 2018). With the production of their calcareous shells, both planktonic and benthic foraminifera actively contribute to the biological carbon pump (Grigoratou et al., 2022; Schiebel, 2002). However, quantifying their contribution to carbon export in the geological past has been hampered by the lack of estimates of their biomass. Although foraminifera are a very powerful tool for paleoceanographic and paleoclimatic studies, these studies have almost exclusively been based on the assemblage composition, species abundance data or biogeochemical proxies, whereas very little is known about the fluctuations in foraminifera biomass in response to changes in environmental parameters. Planktonic foraminifera biomass is mainly controlled by temperature during the early stage of their development, but food availability becomes more important for adults (Grigoratou et al., 2019), whereas benthic foraminifera biomass is tightly linked to organic matter fluxes and oxygenation (Milker et al., 2019).

Ostracods are very sensitive to changes in the oxygen content of seawater (Huang et al., 2019), and paleoclimatic changes associated with the MPT severely affected the ostracod fauna composition and abundance in many areas worldwide (DeNinno et al., 2015; Huang et al., 2019) including the Mediterranean (Rossi et al., 2018).

Sponges are very attuned to seawater depth, pH, temperature, and oxygenation, making their assemblages and abundance very good indicators of paleoenvironmental conditions (Łukowiak, 2020). Sponge spicules in the sediment, reflecting biogenic silica accumulation over the MPT, have been used as a proxy of sea bottom conditions, reflecting cool, oxygen-rich water masses (Alvarez et al., 2017; Auer et al., 2021).

Fish respond swiftly to unfavorable environmental conditions by adjusting their geographic and depth distribution range (Perry et al., 2005), but changes in temperature, salinity, oxygenation and the availability of food eventually lead to eco-evolutionary shifts in their growth and mortality rates, size at maturity, and life-history patterns (Gallo and Levin, 2016; Lindmark et al., 2022; Rountrey et al., 2014). The MPT has already been shown to have affected the distribution and body size of fishes (Agiadi et al., 2018, 2023).

Mesopelagic fish of the family Myctophidae link trophic levels and play an essential role in the biological carbon pump through their diel vertical migration (Pinti et al., 2023). Diel vertical migration (DVM) is the daily movement of several marine organisms, including the mesopelagic fishes of the family Myctophidae, between the twilight (day-time) and the euphotic (night-time) zones (Brierley, 2014). Because these fishes feed at the surface and excrete and respire carbon at depth, their DVM leads to a net drawdown of carbon from the surface waters. According to some estimates, DVM contributes approximately 20% of the biological carbon pump in modern oceans, with more than 1 PgC/y being actively transported below the euphotic zone by all migrating organisms (Aumont et al., 2018). Compared with any other process of the biological carbon pump, carbon is directly injected deeper through the DVM (Aumont et al., 2018). As a result, the contribution of DVM to carbon sequestration accounts for to more than 50% of the global total, and mesopelagic fishes contribute half of this total (Aksnes et al., 2023; Pinti et al., 2023). The capacity of myctophids to perform DVM varies by species and is affected by seawater conditions, as are food availability and type (Olivar et al., 2018). Nothing is known about these regular movements of fishes in the geological past.

In this study, we investigate the responses of the pelagic ecosystem to changes in sea surface temperature, salinity, and primary productivity and relate these responses to the contemporaneous important climate changes that occurred during the MPT, between 923 and 756 kyr B.P., largely overlapping with MIS 23–MIS 18. We quantify changes in sea surface temperature (SST), sea surface salinity (SSS), and productivity. We use the findings to further tie the events to the observed changes in important groups of pelagic life forms, namely planktonic foraminifera and ostracods (zooplankton), benthic foraminifera and sponges (benthos), and fishes (nekton). Using the isotopic compositions of foraminifera shells and fish otoliths, we infer the thermohaline gradient, detect shifts in the depth distribution and diel vertical migration patterns of myctophids, and derive changes in fish metabolism.

sec.title: Study area, sampling and chronostratigraphic background
sec.p: The material used in this study originates from the Lindos Bay Formation exposed at Lardos, northeastern Rhodes, Greece (Fig. 1a). On the island of Rhodes, the Mesozoic–Paleogene limestone substratum is overlain by marine siliciclastic–carbonate Pleistocene deposits. Since the Pliocene, the compressive regime of this area of the Hellenic forearc and the concomitant opening of the > 4000 m deep Rhodes Basin have triggered rapid vertical tectonic motions resulting in the deposition and uplift of Pleistocene marine sediments that are now exposed along the eastern coast of the island (Cornée et al., 2006, 2019; Van Hinsbergen et al., 2007). The Early–Middle Pleistocene hemipelagic sediments of the Lindos Bay Formation sampled for this study were deposited at bathyal depths during the maximum flooding of this tectonically driven transgression–regression cycle (Cornée et al., 2019; Milker et al., 2017; Quillévéré et al., 2019). This occurrence of Pleistocene deep-water sediments accessible on land is unique for the Eastern Mediterranean, providing a valuable reference point for studying the Early–Middle Pleistocene marine faunas of the region (Quillévéré et al., 2016).

The studied section (36°05'19.5"N 28°00'35.9"E) is located at the northern flank of a hill positioned ∼900 m southwest of the village of Lardos. The total section comprises 30 meters of marine marls and silts. In this work, we focus on the 2.4 m lowest marls of the section already studied by Titschack et al. (2013), and we dug a pit beneath them to extend the MPT record to a total thickness of 3.1 m. Thirty-two samples were obtained every 10 cm after the outcrop surface was refreshed.

A chronostratigraphic framework has been previously established for this section on the basis of nannoplankton and foraminiferal biostratigraphic analyses, oxygen isotopic compositions of surface-dwelling planktonic foraminifera, and U234/U238 dating of deep-water Desmophyllum pertusum coral fragments collected in an ∼25–cm-thick horizon at ∼2.3 m section height, which yielded mean ages of 755.2 ± 15.5 and 756.0 ± 17.5 kyr (Titschack et al., 2013). Taken together, these data revealed that the lowermost part of the Lardos section recovers the Early–Middle Pleistocene boundary (774 kyr) and the MPT interval between Marine Isotope Stage (MIS) 22 (partim) and MIS 18. By digging a pit at the base of the section, we extend the record down to MIS 23. In addition, by comparing new local δ18Ο compositions of monospecific samples of benthic and planktonic foraminifera (see subsection 2.5) to those occurring in the global ocean (Lisiecki and Raymo, 2005) and Mediterranean reference records (Konijnendijk et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2010), we aim to refine the location in the section of climatic cycle terminations within the MIS 23–18 interval.

sec.title: Paleodepth estimates
sec.p: The 32 sediment samples were dried in an oven, weighed and placed in water and Calgon for five hours on a shaker table. The samples were subsequently sieved through a 63-μm mesh sieve and dried in an oven at 60 °C, after which the residues were weighed. The depositional depths through the 3.1 m sedimentary unit were assessed by counting the number of planktonic foraminifera P relative to the total number of planktonic and benthic foraminifera (P+B) (up to 300 planktonic foraminifera) in representative splits of the >125 µm size fraction of the 32 collected samples. Indeed, the planktonic/benthic ratio %P(P+B) typically increases with water depth or distance from shorelines (Gibson, 1989). We estimated the paleodepth D via the transfer function developed by van der Zwaan et al. (1990) (Eq. 1): (1)D=e3.58718+0.03534×%P/(P+B)

Several limiting factors play a significant role in controlling benthic and/or planktonic foraminifera depth distribution, notably the sensitivity of benthic foraminifera assemblages to changes in the oxygen levels of the bottom waters (Jorissen et al., 1995), thus leading to potentially biased paleodepth estimates. We consequently followed the methodology proposed by van der Zwaan et al. (1990), discarding from the counts the infaunal benthic genera Uvigerina, Bolivina, Bulimina, Globobulimina and Fursenkoina as characteristic of organic-rich and oxygen-deficient environments.

sec.title: Oxygen and carbon isotope analyses
sec.p: The stable oxygen (δ18Ο) and carbon (δ 13C) isotopic compositions were first measured on ground bulk sedimentary rock samples of the 32 collected horizons. The δ18Ο and δ13C values were also measured on shells of benthic (Uvigerina peregrina) and planktonic foraminifera (Globigerinoides ruber, Globoconella inflata), planktonic ostracods (Bairdopilata spp.), and fish otoliths (Hygophum benoiti, Ceratoscopelus maderensis).

Uvigerina peregrina, which occurs continuously in the section, is a shallow infaunal benthic species whose δ18Ο and δ13C values mirror the physical conditions and compositions of ambient bottom waters at the time of calcification. Time-series analysis of δ18Ο values measured in Uvigerina peregrina constitutes a powerful practical tool for global–scale correlation (Elderfield et al., 2012). Globigerinoides ruber, which also occurs continuously in the section, is a symbiont bearing planktonic species that preferably calcifies in the oligotrophic upper-most part of the water column (Schiebel and Hemleben, 2017). Globoconella inflata occurs in 29 out of the 32 collected samples and is an algal symbiont-barren planktonic species that calcifies mainly at intermediate depths of the photic zone in stratified water masses or in nutrient-rich surface waters (Schiebel and Hemleben, 2017). All δ18O and δ13C measurements on foraminifera were performed on shells handpicked from the 250–355 µm size fraction. About 10 to 15, 20 to 25 and 15 to 20 shells of U. peregrina, G. ruber and G. inflata, respectively, were analyzed per sample to supply sufficient calcium carbonate and to limit the effect of individual variation on the isotopic values (Agiadi et al., 2024b). The foraminifera shells analyzed were free of carbonate infilling or visible dissolution features. The samples were ultrasonically cleaned in distilled water, and weighed prior to isotopic analyses.

We also measured the δ18Ο and δ13 C isotopic compositions of Bairdopilata spp. ostracods (2 to 4 valves per sample), which were found in 15 out of the 32 collected samples, and those of otoliths of the mesopelagic fish species Hygophum benoiti (9 samples) and Ceratoscopelus maderensis (8 samples) (Agiadi et al., 2024b).

Otoliths are aragonitic, incremental hard parts of the inner ear of teleost fishes, which are metabolically inert (Campana, 1999). Their δ18Ο values depend on temperature and the δ18Ο values of ambient water, and they are not affected by fish somatic or otolith growth (Kalish, 1991a). In a paleoceanographic setting, it has also been shown that the δ18O values of otoliths of epipelagic fish closely follow those of planktonic foraminifera, whereas the δ18O values of benthic fish otoliths fall within the range of those measured in benthic foraminifera from the same sediment samples (Agiadi et al., 2024a). The δ13C of otoliths reflects the δ13C of the fish diet and that of the dissolved inorganic carbon, and it is therefore a proxy of the fish metabolic rate (Chung et al., 2019a, b; Kalish, 1991a; Martino et al., 2020; Smoliński et al., 2021; Solomon et al., 2006; Trueman et al., 2016, 2023). In fossil fish otoliths, δ13C has already been successfully used as a metabolic proxy (Agiadi et al., 2024a; Wurster and Patterson, 2003).

The two fish species were selected because they are among the most common myctophid species still living today in the Mediterranean (Mytilineou et al., 2005; Olivar et al., 2012), with very broad geographic distributions (Eduardo et al., 2021; Olivar et al., 2017; Zelck and Klein, 1995), and they are the most abundant in the Pleistocene fossil record (Agiadi et al., 2010, 2011, 2018, 2023; Girone et al., 2006).

All the ostracods and otoliths were sonicated in MeOH for about 10 s to remove adhering clay particles, rinsed at least five times in ultraclean water and dried under a clean-air flow. Randomly selected specimens were observed under a stereoscope to confirm their good preservation state (Agiadi et al., 2022; Antonarakou et al., 2019; Dufour et al., 2000). For the otoliths, a single specimen per sample was crushed, homogenized and analyzed.

The bulk samples were dried and drilled with a manual electric drill at the SBiK-F laboratory after being tested with HCl 10% for carbonate presence. The obtained powder was weighed and calibrated against standard reference materials (Carrara marble, NBS 18 and Merck). The δ18Ο and δ13C ratios were analyzed at Goethe University, Germany, using a Thermo Scientific MAT 253 mass spectrometer coupled to a GasBench II type with continuous flow using the calibration of Spötl and Vennemann (2003). Isotopic values were calculated against a CO2 reference gas with a precision of 0.008‰ for δ18Ο and 0.06‰ for δ13C. All values are presented with respect to Vienna Pee Dee Belemnite (VPDB).

The foraminifera, ostracod, and otolith δ18Ο and δ13C measurements were performed using an Elemental Multiprep system in line with a dual Inlet IsoPrime™ Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometer (IRMS) at the Université Claude Bernard Lyon 1, France. The principle of the fully automated device is to react the calcium carbonates of foraminifera, ostracods or otoliths with anhydrous phosphoric acid at 90 °C to generate CO2, which is then analyzed with IRMS. Isotopic compositions were quoted in the standard δ notation in per mil (‰) relative to V-PDB for both 18O/16O and 13C/12C. All sample measurements were adjusted to the international reference NBS18 (δ18OV-PDB = −23.2‰; δ 13C V-PDB = −5.01‰) and an in-house Carrara Marble standard (δ 18OV-PDB = −1.84‰; δ 13C V-PDB = +2.03‰) calibrated against international references NBS18 and NBS19. With the Carrara marble, the repeatability of the δ 18O and δ 13C measurements was 0.16‰ and 0.08‰ (2σ, n = 32), respectively. With NBS18, the repeatability of the δ 18O and δ 13C measurements was 0.24‰ and 0.16‰ (2σ, n = 16), respectively. Replicate analyses of 13 foraminifera, 3 ostracod and 20 otolith samples generated replicate data within the repeatability of the method for both δ 18O and δ 13C (Agiadi et al., 2024b).

sec.title: Biomarker analysis and sea surface temperature reconstruction
sec.p: The biomarker analyses followed standard grinding, extraction, purification, and measurements detailed elsewhere (Besiou et al., 2024). Briefly, between 30 and 60 g of all 32 collected samples were dried and powdered. Lipids were extracted using a Soxhlet apparatus with a mixture of dichloromethane (DCM) and methanol (MeOH) (7.5:1; v:v) and pre-extracted cellulose filters. All extracts were evaporated to near dryness under N2 flow with a TurboVap LV, obtaining the total lipid extracts (TLE). Subsequently, elemental sulfur was removed using 10% HCl-activated and neutralized, and solvent-cleaned Cu shreds. The TLE vials containing the activated Cu and magnetic rods were stirred overnight on a rotary plate. The samples were then filtered over a Na2SO4 column, dried, and desulfurized again until no reaction with Cu could be observed. A fraction of the TLE was separated into fractions by solid-phase SiO2 gel column chromatography based on mixtures of solvents of increasing polarity. The apolar fraction was eluted using a mixture of n-hexane and DCM (9:1, v:v), the ketone fraction using DCM, and the polar fraction using a mixture of DCM/MeOH (1:1, v:v). The ketone fraction was analyzed using Gas Chromatography Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS), but the samples presented only seldom traces of alkenones, which could not be used for complementary SS reconstruction as initially intended. The polar fraction containing glycerol dialkyl glycerol tetraethers (GDGTs) was dried under N2, dissolved in a 1 ml mixture of n-hexane (n-hexane)/isopropanol (IPA) (99:1, v:v), dispersed for ∼30 s using an ultrasonic bath, then filtered over a 0.45 mm PTFE filter using a 1 ml syringe, and subsequently concentrated. The filtered polar fraction was measured using a Shimadzu HPLC, with two UHPLC silica columns (2.1 × 150 mm, 1.7 μm) in series, connected to a 2.1 × 5 mm pre-column coupled to an ABSciex 3200 Qtrap chemical ionization mass spectrometer (HPLC/APCIeMS) at SbiK-F. The column temperature was 30 °C and the flow rate was 0.2 ml × min-1. The GDGTs were eluted isocratically using 18% B for 25 min, then a linear gradient to 35% B in 25 min, followed by a ramp to 100% B in 30 min, where B in n-hexane/isopropanol (9:1; v:v) and A is n-hexane. For each sample a 5 µl injection volume was used and GDGT detection was achieved through single ion monitoring for selected scanned masses: 1018, 1020, 1022, 1032, 1034, 1036, 1046, 1048, 1050, 1292, 1296, 1298, 1300, and 1302. The quantification of GDGTs was performed using the Analyst software and the peaks were integrated manually, more than twice for each sample to control for human-induced analytical bias. Because of the absence and/or traces of alkenones we were unable to estimate SST using the UK’37 paleothermometer. However, we found easily identifiable amounts of isoprenoidal (iso)GDGTs produced mainly by Archaea (Schouten et al., 2013) in open marine settings. Consequently, we applied TEX86 paleothermometry (Kim et al., 2010; Schouten et al., 2002) to estimate the sea surface temperature (SST), as follows (Schouten et al., 2002) (Eq. 2): (2)TEX86=[GDGT−2]+[GDGT−3]+[Cren′][GDGT−1]+[GDGT−2]+[GDGT−3]+[Cren′], where GDGT-1, GDGT-2, GDGT-3 and Cren’ are isoprenoid GDGTs. TEX86 values were converted into SSTs using the calibration and recommendation of Kim et al. (2010) to apply TEX86H > 15 °C for regions outside the polar and subpolar latitudes as follows (Eqs. 3 and 4): (3)TEX86H=log(TEX86)andtheSSTbasedonTEX86H(TEX86H-SST) (4)TEX86H−SST=68.4×(GDGTindex-2)+38.6,(r2=0.87,p<0.0001) where (Eq. 5): (5)GDGTindex−2=log[GDGT−2]+[GDGT−3]+[Cren′][GDGT−1]+[GDGT−2]+[GDGT−3]+[Cren′],

SST calculations based on TEX86H have a calibration residual standard (1σ) error of ± 2.5 °C (based on 255 core-top sediments using Kim et al. (2010) calibration equation) (Agiadi et al., 2024b). The temperature error between sample replicates was ±0.3 °C. Thus, the propagated error in the temperature estimates is ±2.52 °C.

sec.title: Organic matter content and sources
sec.p: Productivity proxies produce different results depending on the setting and origin of the organic matter (Rühlemann et al., 1996). Relative changes in total productivity were estimated from the TOC content and the bulk δ13C, considering the sedimentary C/N ratio to distinguish between marine and terrestrial organic matter, as well as changes in the sedimentation rate that are expected between glacials and interglacials (El Frihmat et al., 2015). Sample preparation included grinding, removal of inorganic carbon (using 10 % HCl for 24 h at 40 °C), centrifugation (4 × at 2800 to 3000 rpm for 4 to 8 min), and sample drying (24 h at 40 °C). About 8 to 10 mg of sample were analyzed with a Flash EA 1112 that was coupled to a Thermo Fisher MAT 253 gas-source isotope ratio mass spectrometer at the SBiK-F. An uncertainty of 0.2 ‰ was indicated for measured δ13CTOC values by analyzing USGS 24 and IAEA-CH-7 standard materials on a daily basis and replicate measurements of reference materials and samples. The total organic carbon concentrations (in %) have been calculated by relating the signal size of the samples and the averaged signal size of the daily standards (USGS 24, n = 8). A typical error of ∼0.5 % based on mass spectrometric analysis and maxi- mum differences of ∼7 % in TOC contents of replicate measurements (including weighing uncertainties) was detected.

To evaluate the relative input of terrestrial organic matter for coastal versus marine organic matter we used Branched Isoprenoid Tetraether (BIT) index (Hopmans et al., 2004; Weijers et al., 2006), a biomarker-based proxy calculated as (Eq. 6) (Agiadi et al., 2024b): (6)BIT=[(GDGT−I)+(GDGT−II)+(GDGT−III)]/[(Crenarchaeol)+GDGT−I)+(GDGT−II)+(GDGT−III) where GDGT-I, GDGT-II and GDGT-III are branched (br)GDGTs, which are components of bacterial cell membranes (particularly from Acidobacteria found in terrestrial, estuarine, and marine environments (Sinninghe Damsté et al., 2011; Weijers et al., 2006). Crenarchaeol is an isoGDGT and, together with brGDGTs, was analyzed and isolated as explained in section 2.4 (Agiadi et al., 2024b).

sec.title: Foraminifera biomasses, ostracod and sponge spicule counts
sec.p: The sediment samples were dry-sieved into seven size categories: < 125 μm, 125–150 μm, 150–200 μm, 200–250 μm, 250–315 μm, 315–400 μm, 400–500 μm, and > 500 μm. The < 125-μm residuals were excluded from the analyses following (Milker et al., 2017; van der Zwaan et al., 1990). We counted the number of planktonic and benthic foraminifera, ostracod valves, and sponge spicules in each size fraction. For foraminifera and ostracods, we only counted individuals whose shell or valve was at least half-preserved.

We estimated the planktonic foraminifera biomass (pfb) based on the empirical relationship between test size and protein mass (equivalent of biomass) developed by Schiebel and Movellan (2012) for 26 planktonic foraminifera species (Eq. 7): (7)M=3.889×10−4×d1.48 where M is the mass of the protein content (μg) and d is the minimum diameter of the indivitual (μm). The benthic foraminifera biomass (bfb) was estimated using the relationship of Movellan et al. (2012) for Ammonia tepida (Eq. 8): (8)M=5.537×10−8×d2.941

The total foraminifera biomasses (fb), pfb, and bfb (total and for each size class) are then calculated as the M times the number of tests counted in the sample or fraction divided by the dry weight of the sediment sample in g. Ostracod and sponge spicules were counted at each sediment fraction and reported here as the number of valves or spicule fragments, respectively, per gram of sediment. Sponge spicule abundance is related to the abundance of sponge individuals (Łukowiak, 2020).

sec.title: Sea surface salinity estimates
sec.p: Foraminifera δ18O records reflect both the temperature and the ambient oxygen isotopic composition of seawater (δ18Osw) in which the shells precipitated. δ18Osw, in turn, is influenced by global ice volume and ocean salinity. When the temperature (T) component is accounted for, foraminifera calcite δ18O can be used to estimate past salinity changes, as δ18Osw covaries linearly with sea surface salinity (SSS). Both increase with evaporation and decrease with the addition of low-δ18O freshwater (Legrande and Schmidt, 2006).

Building on this concept and in line with earlier studies (Kontakiotis et al., 2022; Vasiliev et al., 2019), we employed a multiproxy geochemical approach to estimate regional past SSS variability. To isolate δ18OSW from the measured foraminifera δ18O values, we used δ18O measurements from Globigerinoides ruber shells (δ18Orub), the most surface-dwelling species. The temperature component was removed using the Orbulina universa low-light paleotemperature equation of Bemis et al. (1998), which is widely regarded as the most accurate for estimating paleo-SST in symbiotic planktonic foraminifera from subtropical settings in deep time (Williams et al., 2005).

Removing the temperature component from the δ18O record using the paleotemperature equation enables the estimation of salinity. To account for the effect of continental ice volume, we utilized the Pleistocene eustatic sea-level curve of Rohling et al. (2014). Specifically, we linearly interpolated the sea-level curve to the studied time period and generated a record of global δ18OSW changes associated with the melting of continental ice sheets during the Early–Middle Pleistocene. This was achieved by converting the sea-level data into mean ocean δ18O changes and applying a 0.011‰ increase per meter of sea-level drop (Fairbanks and Matthews, 1978; Lea et al., 2002; Schrag et al., 1996). Furthermore, the δ18O values of G. ruber were corrected for species-specific disequilibria from ambient seawater equilibrium ("vital effects") by applying a 0.48‰ adjustment (Peeters et al., 2002; Pracht et al., 2019). We then subtracted this component from the δ18OSW profile to derive the regional ice volume-free residual (δ18OIVF-SW). The calculated δ18OIVF-SW values reflect changes in regional hydrography and are therefore considered to approximate local variations in sea surface salinity (SSS). To convert the δ18Orub signal into absolute SSS values, we applied the modern δ18OSW–salinity relationship for the Mediterranean Sea of Pierre (1999) that refers to the surface waters with salinities greater than 36.2 (Eq. 9): (9)δ18O=0.25(±0.02)∗S−8.2(±0.96)

The uncertainty in salinity estimates arises from the propagation of errors associated with temperature estimates, δ18OSW reconstructions, and the δ18OSW–salinity calibration equation. As demonstrated above, the error in the temperature estimates is 2.5 °C. Based on the δ18O analytical error and the error associated with the paleotemperature equation, the propagation error for δ18O is 0.63‰. Using the δ18OSW – salinity relationship from Pierre (1999), the average propagated uncertainty in salinity reconstruction is calculated to be ∼5.4. In the accompanying graphs, the propagated salinity error was calculated for each sample individually, using the sample-specific δ18OSW residual.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: To detect regime shifts, we first checked the time series of all the variables measured for normality using the Shapiro-Wilk test. For the variables whose values did not exhibit a normal distribution, we applied the L-method, which is based on the Mann-Whitney U test (Lanzante, 1996). For the variables whose values were normally distributed, we used the Sequential T-test Analysis of Regime-Shifts (STARS), which is additionally robust at the ends of the time series (Rodionov, 2004), setting Huber’s weight parameter to 1 and the window size arbitrarily to 10. For both the L-method and the Rodionov’s method, the p-value was set at 0.05.

Correlation was performed between: a) SST and all the δ18Ο values (for bulk sediments, foraminifers, ostracods and otoliths); b) TOC (as a proxy of productivity and preservation of organic matter) and all the δ13C values; c) SST and foraminifera biomasses (fb, pfb, bfb); d) TOC and the δ13C in bulk sediment and foraminifers, against the foraminifera biomasses; e) SST and the ostracod weighted average body size; and f) TOC and the δ13C in bulk sediment and foraminifers, against the ostracod body size. In all cases, we used the Spearman rank correlation coefficient (95% confidence level). The above analyses were performed in R (version 4.3.3) (R Development Core Team, 2024) with the package rshift (Room et al., 2020).

sec.title: Lifetime-average depth of mesopelagic fish
sec.p: The foraminifera δ18O data represent the thermohaline gradient in the southeastern Aegean through time, and, with certain assumptions, are used here to estimate the position of the fishes in the water column. An exponential model is fitted using a log-linear regression on the δ18O values of foraminifera living at different depths to infer lifetime-average depths of the two common mesopelagic fish species, Ceratoscopelus maderensis and Hygophum benoiti, at each individual climatic cycle. The benthic foraminifera Uvigerina peregrina occupies the sea bottom and the depth used in our model is the paleodepth estimated in each sample based on the %P/(B+P) ratio. We assigned a distribution of 100–300 m to Globoconella inflata, assuming that this relatively deep-dwelling planktonic foraminifera is consistently most abundant at cool and nutrient-rich subsurface depths (Rohling et al., 2004; Schiebel and Hemleben, 2017). We finally assigned a distribution depth of 10–50 m to Globigerinoides ruber, assuming that this surface-dweller is most abundant at warmer and oligotrophic surface mixed-layer depths (Rohling et al., 2004; Schiebel and Hemleben, 2017).

Since direct measurements of depth (y) were not available for the planktonic foraminifera, we simulated the values within the ecological depth ranges of each species. For each species, depths were drawn from a uniform distribution over the respective depth ranges, assuming equal probability across the range.

We fit an exponential model using a log-linear regression where the realizations of our response variable yi represent the observed depths of any foraminiferal species. The response variable was log-transformed during modeling to establish an exponential relationship with δ18O (x) (Eq. 10): (10)log(yi)=β0+β1x+ei,ei∼N(0,σ),i=1,…,n where we assume that log(yi) follows a normal distribution and that the linear predictor is made of an intercept β0 and the relationship with δ18O. Separate models were fitted for glacial and interglacial cycles to account for potential differences in the δ18O-depth relationships between these periods.

Using the model at each individual MIS, we thus estimated the fish lifetime-average depth based on their otolith δ18O values. This model approach assumes that the thermal gradient remains the same within each MIS and that the water column is always well mixed. Although this is a simplified model of thermohaline conditions, the outputs offer a valuable perspective on the evolution of the lifetime-average depth and DVM patterns of mesopelagic fishes. The code for our model is available in (Fuster-Alonso et al., 2024).

sec.title: Paleodepths
sec.p: The %P/(P+B) ratio ranges between 45% and 76%, and the 32 collected samples consequently deposited at the outer shelf (5 samples) and upper bathyal (27 samples) depths, with paleodepths D estimates ranging between ∼176 m and ∼528 m. Although absolute paleodepth values based on %P(P+B) need to be taken very cautiously (Van Hinsbergen et al., 2007; van der Zwaan et al., 1990), three main intervals with lower approximate values around ∼200 m are recorded in the lower part of the section at heights between 40 and 60 cm, in the middle part of the section between 170 and 180 cm, and in the uppermost part of the studied deposits above 270 cm (Fig. 1). Overall, the highest upper bathyal depths are reached at three main intervals: below the height of 40 cm, between 70 and 160 cm, and between 190 and 270 cm.

sec.title: Oxygen and carbon isotopic compositions
sec.p: The δ18O values of bulk sediments (δ18Obulk) vary between −2.82 (LR30) and −0.70 ‰ (LR16) (Agiadi et al., 2024b). They are relatively higher overall up to height 160 cm, and lower thereafter. The δ13Cbulk values range from −2.68 (LR25) to −0.96 ‰ (LR12) (Agiadi et al., 2024b). Lower values appear in general until LR16 and higher thereafter.

δ18Oruber values range from −0.62 (LR08) to 1.22 ‰ (LR01), δ18Oinflata from 1.23 (LR17) to 2.19 ‰ (LR01), and δ18Operegrina from 1.51 (LR22) to 2.56 ‰ (LR30). The three species of foraminifera exhibit δ18O values that reflect their depth-related ecology, with higher values in the benthic species Uvigerina peregrina, and lower δ18O values in the surface mixed-layer species Globigerinoides ruber (Fig. 2). Globoconella inflata exhibit intermediate δ18O values that are closer to those of U. peregrina (0.5 ‰ average gradient) than to those of G. ruber (1.7 ‰ average gradient), then confirming that G. inflata mineralized at cooler/deeper water depths than G. ruber. Globigerinoides ruber and U. peregrina exhibit an average gradient of 1.9 ‰ between surface and bottom waters. Uvigerina peregrina, G. inflata and G. ruber show similar overall variation trends throughout the section, but with discrepancies notably recorded between G. ruber and the two other species. We were only able to find valves of the ostracod genus Bairdopilata at the upper part of the section. δ18Obaird ranges from 1.93 (LR28) to 5.69 ‰ (LR30).

For the fishes, δ18Obenoiti ranges from 2.56 (LR28) to 7.35 ‰ (LR02), and δ18Omader ranges from −3.3 (LR16) to 3.50 ‰ (LR10). There is no significant correlation between otolith weight and δ18O. δ13Cruber ranges from −0.18 (LR02) to 1.13 ‰ (LR19), with lower values until LR07. δ13Cinflata ranges from −0.2 (LR17) to 0.58 ‰ (LR07), and δ13Cperegrina ranges from −0.89 (LR16) to −0.3 ‰ (LR10). Ostracod δ13Cbaird, only measured in the upper part of the section, ranges from −1.18 (LR28) to −0.61 ‰ (LR25). For the fishes, δ13Cbenoiti ranges from −5.25 (LR32) to 0.99 ‰ (LR09), with generally more negative values in the upper part of the section, and δ13Cmader ranges from −6.70 (LR07) to 2.92 ‰ (LR16). The distributions of the δ13Cmader and δ13Cbenoiti values are shown in Fig. S1. There is significant correlation between otolith weight and otolith δ13C for both Hygophum benoiti (rho = 0.45, p = 0.04) and Ceratoscopelus maderensis (rho = 0.80, p = 0.0003). The different foraminifera and fish species show distinctive patterns of δ13C and δ18O (Fig. S2).

sec.title: Refining the age model
sec.p: We used the new local oxygen isotope stratigraphy and paleodepth estimates from this work to refine the published chronostratigraphy of the studied deposits (Titschack et al., 2013). At heights of 30 to 40 cm (LR04–05), the δ18O values of all three species of foraminifera increase and the paleodepth shows a sharp decrease. Such changes are proposed to correlate with those occurring in the LR04 global (Lisiecki and Raymo, 2005) and Mediterranean (Konijnendijk et al., 2015) benthic δ18O stacks, and with that occurring in the planktonic foraminifera Mediterranean δ18O Medstack (Wang et al., 2010) between MIS 23 and MIS 22 (Fig. 1). In this re-examination of the age model of the Lardos section, we assign the MIS 22/21 termination (866 kyr; Lisiecki and Raymo, 2005) to the height of 65 cm, in accordance with Titschack et al. (2013). Such a level, characterized by a change in the slope in all foraminifera δ18O records and a sharp increase in paleodepth, is proposed in agreement with those occurring in open-ocean reference records (Fig. 1). We also delineate the MIS 21/20 (814 kyr) and MIS 20/19 (790 kyr) terminations to the heights 165 (LR17–18) and 185 cm (LR19–20), respectively. Within the sedimentary interval that we allocate to MIS 20, and that shows shallower paleodepths, both U. peregrina and G. ruber exhibit increasing δ18O values similar to those of open-ocean reference records (Fig. 1). Finally, we assign the MIS 19/18 termination (761 kyr) to the height of 275 cm (LR29–30), in accordance with the previously published chronostratigraphy (Titschack et al., 2013). Such a level shows increasing δ18O values in all foraminifera taxa, similar to the open-ocean records, and a sharp decrease in paleodepth.

Based on these tie-points, we estimate the average sedimentation rates for the deposits within each climate cycle in the MIS 22–19 interval. The sedimentation rates within MIS 22 and MIS 19 are then linearly extrapolated to MIS 23 and MIS 18, respectively. According to this refined age model, the samples analyzed in this study were deposited within the MIS 23–18 interval between ∼923 and ∼756 kyr. The age estimate of each sample (Agiadi et al., 2024b) is used for the results and discussions on the observed changes during the MPT at Lardos.

sec.title: TEXH86-SST and SSS
sec.p: SST ranges from 19.2 to 26.1 °C (Fig. 2). From 923 to 864 kyr, SST decreases to 20.5 °C. The interval 861–858 kyr exhibits higher temperature, but afterwards it is low until 820 kyr, when it starts to increase to a maximum of 24.4 °C around 798 kyr. Between 788 and 762 kyr, SST shows intermediate, but rather stable values fluctuating around 23 °C, and then increases until 756 kyr to 25.9 °C.

SSS ranges from 31.9 to 42.3 (Fig. 2). From 923 to 864 kyr, SSS decreases to 31.9, but 861–858 kyr experiences the highest SSS values. Afterwards, SS decreases again and shows intermediate values after 760 kyr.

sec.title: Organic content in the sediments
sec.p: The BIT index is lower in the older part of the section (i.e., greater input of marine organic matter), with a minimum of 0.45 at 870 kyr (Fig. 3). It then increases (toward more terrestrial organic matter) to reach a maximum of 0.80 at 815–808 kyr and remains high in the younger part of the section. TOC ranges from 0.152 to 0.266% and TN from 0.027 to 0.042%, making the C/N ratio range from 5.14 to 7.27 (Fig. 3). From 923 kyr, both TOC and TN increase to reach 0.266% and 0.042%, respectively, at 864 kyr. In the interval 861–820 kyr, they show relatively high values, which then decrease to a minimum at 798 kyr of 0.180 and 0.032%, respectively. Intermediate values appear from 788 to 762 kyr, and then low values for both TOC and TN until 756 kyr.

sec.title: Foraminifera biomass
sec.p: The foraminifera biomass is mostly composed of plankton (pfb), which is much greater than benthos (bfb) at all levels: the minimum is found at 756 kyr (88.3 µg/g for fb, 58.8 µg/g for pfb, and 29.4 µg/g for bfb), whereas the maximum biomass is found at 766 kyr (1763.3 µg/g for fb, 1518.2 µg/g for pfb, and 245.1 µg/g for bfb) (Fig. 4). For both pfb and bfb, the contributions of the size classes to the total biomass varies greatly (Figs. S3 and S4). From 923 to 880 kyr, both pfb and bfb are low, and then they increase to peak at 861 kyr (867.7 µg/g and 240.4 µg/g, respectively). They remain high until 815 kyr, and then decrease until 788 kyr (minima are 303.5 µg/g at 798 kyr and 60.7 µg/g at 788 kyr, respectively). In general, bfb covaries with pfb, with two exceptions, at 774 and 769 kyr, where bfb is particularly low (77.6 and 66.5 µg/g).

sec.title: Ostracod and sponge spicule counts
sec.p: The total ostracod abundance ranges from 2 valves/g at 774 kyr to 25 valves/g at 758 kyr (Fig. 4). From 923 to 903 kyr, the medium–high abundance is driven by ostracod valves in the 150–200 μm size-class. The overall number of valves then decreases, and high values are found again from 861 to 820 kyr, when their abundance increases across size classes. The abundance after that point fluctuates between low and medium levels, and only shows maximum values at 758 kyr due to highs in the >500, 315–400, and <200 μm size-classes.

The number of sponge spicule fragments per gram of sediment range from 2 at 880 kyr to 18 at 826 kyr (Fig. 4). The weighted average size of the ostracod valves ranges from 159 μm at 903 kyr to 241 μm at 774 kyr. Broadly, similar to ostracod abundance and foraminifera biomass, the values are generally relatively high around 861–820 kyr. The weighted average size of the spicules ranges from 149 μm at 760 kyr to 318 μm at 758 kyr.

sec.title: Fish average depth in the water column
sec.p: Our model shows a steeper δ18O gradient during interglacials than during glacials, predicting greater depth values for fish (Fig. 5). Based on the model results, the lifetime-average depth ranges from 474 m at 870 kyr to 933 m at 839 kyr for Hygophum benoiti and from 330 m at 903 kyr to 1502 m at 858 kyr for Ceratoscopelus maderensis (Fig. 6). We could not detect a significant correlation between the modeled fish depth and otolith weight, which suggests that fish depth is not controlled by life history in the same way throughout the studied interval for either species. Additionally, we did not find any significant correlation between the modeled depth and SST, TOC, or δ13Cbulk.

sec.title: Regime shifts and covariance
sec.p: Positive values of the Regime Shift Index (RSI) indicate the presence of regime shifts (95% confidence level) for: a) TOC, δ18Οperegrina and δ18Οruber at 760 kyr (RSI = 0.940, 1.437 and 0.265, respectively); b) δ13Cperegrina and the ostracod weighted-average body size at 788 kyr (RSI = 0.583 and 0.231, respectively); and c) δ13Cruber at 851 kyr (RSI = 0.788). Additionally, a regime shift was found using the Lanzante method for the sponge weighted average size at 864 kyr (p = 0.006).

Regarding foraminifera biomasses, a medium correlation is detected between: a) SST and benthic foraminifera biomass (rho = −0.44; p = 0.03); b) δ13Cruber and benthic foraminifera biomass (rho = 0.45; p = 0.01); c) δ13Cinflata and total foraminifera biomass (rho = −0.42; p = 0.02), planktonic foraminifera biomass (rho = −0.45; p = 0.014), and the benthic foraminifera biomass (rho = −0.44; p = 0.014); d) δ13Cperegrina and the total foraminifera biomass (rho = −0.47; p = 0.007) and the planktonic foraminifera biomass (rho = −0.53; p = 0.002); and e) δ13Cbulk and the total foraminifera biomass (rho = 0.52; p = 0.003), the planktonic foraminifera biomass (rho = 0.52; p = 0.003), and the benthic foraminifera biomass (rho = 0.42; p = 0.019). Medium correlation is also found between δ13Cperegrina and the ostracod weighted average body size (rho = 0.40; p = 0.02).

sec.title: Climate, productivity and organic carbon burial
sec.p: The unique SST reconstruction for the Eastern Mediterranean that is presented here is not nearly as resolved in time as the equivalent from deep-sea cores in the Western Mediterranean and the Atlantic due to the large difference in sedimentation rates between the sites, highlighting the importance of obtaining SST records from deep-sea drilling sites in the Eastern Mediterranean. The SST in the study area is consistently warmer than those in the Central and Western Mediterranean, with higher mean SST values found in all climate cycles, between MIS 23 and 18 (Table S1; Fig. 7), as observed today (Minnett et al., 2019). The glacial–interglacial SST amplitude is similar (∼5 °C) at both Site LC07 and Lardos, but very different from that recorded at the Atlantic Site U1385 (Fig. 7). The two-fold smaller temperature changes observed at the Mediterranean sites indicate that the basin responded to the global climate change during the MPT, but the recorded temperatures must have also been influenced by the semi-enclosed configuration of the Mediterranean Sea. The SST values from Lardos are also higher than those reconstructed from Site LC07. Part of this difference can be explained by a system similar to the present-day one, where the Eastern Mediterranean is ∼2 °C warmer than the Central Mediterranean is (Minnett et al., 2019). Another part of the difference can also be explained by the different proxies used to obtain the SST estimates, i.e. TEX86 for Lardos and UK´37 for Site LC07. TEX86 generally overestimates SSTs by 2–6 °C (Kim et al., 2015), whereas UK´37 tends to underestimate SSTs by 2–4 °C (Tierney and Tingley, 2018). Importantly, based on the TOC content of the analyzed samples, we could not capture any of the sapropels (Martínez-Dios et al., 2021) in the study area. Four paleoceanographic regimes were identified within the studied time interval in the southeastern Aegean, based on the regime shift analysis: a) 923–858 kyr; b) 851–798 kyr; c) 788–762 kyr; and d) 760–756 kyr.

sec.title: 923–858 kyr
sec.p: The interval between 923 and 858 kyr includes the MIS 23 interglacial, the MIS 22 glacial, and the early part of the MIS 21 interglacial. SST declines from MIS 23 to MIS 22 and increases in MIS 21 (Fig. 2). TOC (and TN) increase throughout the study interval (Fig. 3). Planktonic and benthic foraminifera biomasses are low in MIS 23 and even lower in MIS 22, but increase drastically in MIS 21 (Fig. 4). Overall, stable high values appear for this interval in δ13Cbulk, and δ13Cperegrina shows intermediate values (Fig. 3). δ13Cinflata decreases in the 864–858 kyr interval. In contrast, δ13Cruber values are higher in MIS 23 and MIS 21, and lower in MIS 22.

The TOC and δ13C values of the bulk sediment and foraminifera shells reflect changes in productivity as well as enhanced organic carbon burial (Jing et al., 2024; Spezzaferri, 1995). Benthic foraminifera accumulation rates from deep-sea drilling sites are often used to estimate changes in productivity (Diester-Haass et al., 2018). Our results suggest that productivity during the 923–864 kyr interval fluctuates with climate, as reflected by the values of δ13Cruber (Fig. 3) and the foraminifera biomasses (Fig. 4). In contrast, organic carbon burial declines during the 923–864 kyr interval, since the benthic δ13Cperegrina values remain approximately the same. The regime shift in the sponge weighted average size at 864 kyr is coupled with a large increase in BIT (Fig.3) and foraminifera biomasses, and a decrease in δ18Oinflata and δ18Operegrina (while δ18Oruber remains at the same levels), suggesting lengthening of the thermal gradient in the water column associated with the influx of terrestrial organic matter (i.e., higher BIT) that benefited secondary production.

sec.title: 851–798 kyr
sec.p: This interval encompasses most of the MIS 21 interglacial, after the SST maximum at 858 kyr (Fig. 2), and the MIS 20 glacial. The regime shift in δ13Cruber denotes a paleoenvironmental or ecosystem change in Lardos at 851 kyr. The δ13C of foraminifera is a proxy of the δ13C of dissolved inorganic carbon in the seawater where shell calcification took place, which increases with primary productivity, influx of terrestrial organic matter and water mixing (Ravelo and Hillaire-Marcel, 2007). The lack of regime shifts in δ13Cinflata and δ13Cperegrina implies that surface waters were the most affected by the change. BIT increases to a maximum around the MIS 21/MIS 20 transition (Fig. 3), reflecting more terrestrial organic matter, and both pfb and bfb increase at the same time.

sec.title: 788–762 kyr
sec.p: The interval between 788 and 762 kyr includes the entire MIS 19 and is characterized at Lardos by a regime shift in δ13Cperegrina and the ostracod weighted-average body size. The δ13Cperegrina values during this interval are generally the lowest, while ostracods show a drastic decline in body size with an almost complete absence of sizes > 500 μm. From 780 kyr toward MIS 18, SST indicates a cooling trend (Fig. 2), which was also detected along the Iberian margin and has been related to a progressive southward migration of the polar front (Girone et al., 2023). A decreasing trend is also evident in SSS (Fig. 2) from 780 to 762 kyr. Higher foraminifera (planktonic especially) biomasses are observed throughout the 788–762 kyr interval, as expected since they are significantly correlated with δ13Cperegrina. The lowest values are also observed for δ13Cbulk. Therefore, we propose that higher productivity during MIS 19 was accompanied by enhanced organic carbon burial to explain the concurrent higher planktonic foraminifera biomass and low δ13Cperegrina and δ13Cbulk values. Higher primary productivity and organic carbon burial have been reported at least for the early part of MIS 19 in the Western Mediterranean as well (ODP Site 975; (Marino et al., 2022; Quivelli et al., 2020).

sec.title: 760–756 kyr
sec.p: The interval from 760 to 756 kyr captures the oldest part of MIS 18 at Lardos. SW Europe winter precipitation and the East Asia summer monsoon strength peaked during MIS 18, contributing to the expansion of the Northern Hemisphere ice sheets (Sánchez Goñi et al., 2023). In our study area, the paleoceanographic conditions change at the MIS19–MIS18 transition, as captured by regime shifts in TOC, δ18Οperegrina and δ18Οruber. TOC shows low values (Fig. 3), whereas δ18Οperegrina and δ18Οruber show higher values than in MIS 19 (Fig. 2). However, SST and SSS are not higher than in the early part of MIS 19, but the estimated paleodepth is shallower at this time (Fig. 2). The sea-level change that occurred during MIS 18 and the shallowing of the Lardos area likely explain the observed regime shift.

sec.title: Thermohaline gradient
sec.p: The thermohaline gradient is inferred from the δ18Οruber (corresponding to surface waters), δ18Οinflata (intermediate waters), and δ18Οperegrina (bottom waters) values, considering the paleodepth in the study area (Fig. 2). The gradient between these values is steeper in MIS 23–MIS 22 but attenuates in MIS 21. In the late part of MIS 21, a short warmer period occurs around 820 kyr (Fig. 2), but the differences between the foraminifera δ18Ο values are maintained despite the greater paleodepth, suggesting that the thermohaline gradient is less steep than before. During MIS 20 and MIS 18, the gradient is smaller but this can be explained by the shallower depth during the glacials (Fig. 2). Our model produces steeper thermohaline gradients during interglacials than during glacials (Fig. 5), as expected due to the lower thermal conductivity of water masses.

sec.title: Responses across the food web
sec.p: Planktonic and benthic foraminifera biomass changes closely follow the paleodepth changes recorded in the study area (Fig. 4). Since paleodepths exceed the euphotic zone depth at all times, this observation is unlikely to be due to increased accumulation of shells on the seabed with increasing depth, but rather a genuine signal. Accordingly, higher foraminifera biomass is observed during interglacials than glacials, and this is confirmed by the ostracod and sponge abundances (Fig. 4). Additionally, the planktonic foraminifera in MIS 21 and MIS 19 interglacials are the largest overall, with the > 500 μm size fraction increasing in those intervals. Larger shell sizes in planktonic foraminifera are typically associated with temperature and/or primary productivity conditions that are close to the optimum values for these organisms (Schmidt et al., 2004). Therefore, we can safely assume overall higher secondary production during interglacials.

Otolith δ13C in conjunction with foraminifera δ13C is informative of how the metabolic rate of fishes changes through time (Agiadi et al., 2024a). In this case, no important changes in the otolith δ13C values of the two fish species are observed over time. An exception is the slight drop in δ13Cbenoiti in MIS 18, which is only occurred from one point. In general, a lower δ13Coto reflects a higher metabolic rate or a change to higher trophic-level (and therefore lower δ13C) food items (Chung et al., 2019b). Here, overall, the larger otolith specimens exhibit higher δ13C values, suggesting that, as the animals grew, they consumed fewer and/or switched to lower-trophic–level items. A possible explanation could be that younger individuals consumed much, primarily detritus, whereas adults became more selective, consuming mesozooplankton.

sec.title: Changes in fish diel vertical migration and implications for the carbon pump
sec.p: The δ18Ο values of both mesopelagic fish species are consistently greater than those of foraminifera, which indicates that these fishes experienced much cooler and/or saltier seawater temperatures on average. Otolith δ18Ο is a function of seawater temperature and varies according to the lifestyle of the species in question (Kalish, 1991b, a). Both Ceratoscopelus maderensis and Hygophum benoiti perform DVM. The fact that δ18Οbenoiti and δ18Οmader fluctuate between much more positive and almost the values of δ18Οperegrina suggests that they spend only part of their day in the study location, migrating from greater depths. Furthermore, with the present data, the δ18Οbenoiti and δ18Οmader variability cannot be related to the δ18Οforam or δ18Οbulk variability, nor the SST changes. Particularly, for Ceratoscopelus maderensis, this variability shows high amplitude, suggesting that this species changed its DVM pattern and/or its depth distribution within the studied time interval. Today, the common, extant species Ceratoscopelus maderensis shows different depth ranges in the Atlantic Ocean (Badcock and Merrett, 1976; Killen et al., 2010; Kinzer and Schulz, 1985) than in the Mediterranean Sea, and even within the latter (up to 1480 m in the Levantine Sea (Goren and Galil, 2015), but up to 2500 m in the Ionian Sea (Olivar et al., 2012)). Our δ18Ο–depth model estimates of the lifetime-average depth of the two mesopelagic fishes show high variability.

In MIS 23–22, Ceratoscopelus maderensis (indicated by small otolith specimens corresponding to young individuals) are distributed on average at depths of 330 m (Fig. 6), which is at the very shallow end of the present-day distribution of this species, suggesting that the individuals (at least the young ones) were performing DVM and/or occupying shallow depths (Fig. 8), as observed today in the Mediterranean (Olivar et al., 2012). The modeled depth of Hygophum benoiti is deeper in MIS 23, but the same in MIS 22, as is the case for C. maderensis. However, we cannot interpret this as an absence of DVM by that species in MIS 23, because we have only examined a few specimens per species as replicates. A greater number of otolith specimens should be analyzed per sampling unit to reconstruct the frequency distribution of the lifetime-average depths of each species to be able to confidently exclude DVM. Large adults of both species are distributed at shallower depths (776 and 698 m, respectively) in the later part of MIS 21, and the same pattern is observed in MIS 19.

A drastic shift to greater depth (model estimate: 1502 m) is observed for Ceratoscopelus maderensis in the initial part of MIS 21 (Fig. 6), which similarly indicates slowing down of DVM and/or drastic shift of these fish to much greater mesopelagic depths than before (Fig. 8). These two alternative explanations would have opposite effects on the biological carbon pump and therefore on carbon sequestration and burial. If the depth distribution range of the fishes simply expanded to greater depths but continued to perform DVM, then we would expect to see an increase in organic carbon burial at the time, which is not observed on TOC or δ13C data (Fig. 2). In contrast, we support that the DVM capacity of fishes was hindered by the warming that occurred in the early part of MIS 21, resulting in a reduction in the biological carbon pump efficiency (Fig. 8) and relatively stable carbon burial despite the enhanced terrestrial input (increased BIT; Fig. 3) and subsequent interglacial.

The rather great depths for the distribution of juveniles of both C. maderensis (457 m) and H. benoiti (933 m) around the middle part of MIS 21 reinforce the interpretation of a reduction in DVM, and further signal a gradual re-establishment of regular DVM patterns (replicate data confirming this are available in (Agiadi et al., 2024b)). This event was concurrent with a shift in global and Mediterranean SST (Fig. 7). Although higher resolution and more sites are necessary to investigate the extent of this phenomenon, our results support the hypothesis that warming reduces the biological carbon pump efficiency by restricting mesopelagic zone ecosystem functioning (Boscolo-Galazzo et al., 2021).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: We employed here a multiproxy approach to reconstruct the paleoceanographic conditions and the response of the pelagic ecosystem to their changes between 923 and 756 kyr in the Eastern Mediterranean. Glacial–interglacial changes in the Pleistocene tested the limits of marine ecosystem resilience in multiple ways, resulting in distribution range shifts, ecophenotypic adaptations, and ultimately species extinctions (Agiadi et al., 2011, 2018, 2023; Porz et al., 2024). During the time interval of the study, the Eastern Mediterranean was a warm subtropical area with fluctuating influxes of terrestrial organic matter. The global warm MIS 21 initiation, the sea-level drop in MIS 20, and high productivity accompanied by enhanced organic matter burial during MIS 19 are the most notable environmental changes evidenced in the study area at this time. All the studied fossil groups seem to have been affected by the warming that took place during the early part of MIS 21, with increases in biomass observed for the invertebrate groups (foraminifera, ostracods and sponges) and a reduction in DVM for mesopelagic fishes. Similarly, large variabilities in foraminifera, ostracod and sponge biomasses are observed within the MIS 19 interglacial. However, we could not find evidence of a disruption in the fish DVM pattern in this interval, although the fish abundances and body sizes have been shown to be affected by this interglacial (Agiadi et al., 2023). Planktonic foraminifera biomass was negatively affected by the MIS 20 and MIS 18 glacials. Although our ecosystem-level approach is challenging, it offers a holistic approach for assessing the impacts of paleoenvironmental changes that can be most informative for ecosystem management.

element-citation.article-title: The depth dependency of planktonic/benthic foraminiferal ratios: Constraints and applications

caption.title: Map of the Mediterranean region with present-day SST (Minnett et al., 2019) and the location of Lardos (our study area), LC07 (Martínez-Dios et al., 2021), U1385 (Rodrigues et al., 2017), ODP975 (Quivelli et al., 2020, 2021), and M.J. Montalbano Jonico (Marino et al., 2020; Peral et al., 2020).
caption.p: Paleodepth estimates based on the %P/(B+P) ratio and proposed correlation between foraminifera δ18O records of the Lardos section and open ocean δ18O reference records: the LR04 benthic global δ18O stack (Lisiecki and Raymo, 2005), the benthic Eastern Mediterranean δ18O compilation data from Ocean Drilling Program (ODP) Sites 967 and 968 (Konijnendijk et al., 2015), and the planktonic (Globigerinoides ruber) δ18O Medstack (Wang et al., 2010). The paleodepth changes (with a glacio-eustatic component) and the coincidence of successive positive and negative excursions in the δ18O records allow refining the chronostratigraphy previously published for the section (Titschack et al., 2013). This revised age model reveals the identification of six distinct isotopic stages between MIS 23 and MIS 18, including three interglacials (gray areas) and three glacials (white areas).

caption.title: Paleoclimatic and paleoceanographic conditions at Lardos.
caption.p: Paleodepth estimates based on the %P/(B+P) ratio. δ18O and δ13C values of the surface-dwelling planktonic foraminifera Globigerinoides ruber, the deeper-dwelling planktonic foraminifera Globoconella inflata, and the benthic foraminifera Uvigerina peregrina. TEX86-derived sea surface temperature (SST) and salinity (SSS) data, where bars are used to visualize the ±2.5 °C error. The three red wide-dashed vertical lines indicate the three regime shifts identified using the STARS algorithm (TOC, δ18Οperegrina and δ18Οruber at 760 kyr; δ13Cperegrina and the ostracod weighted average body size at 788 kyr; and δ13Cruber at 851 kyr), whereas the narrow-dashed line shows the regime shift identified using the L-method (ostracod weighted average body size at 864 kyr). Grey-shaded areas represent interglacials, whereas white areas are glacials; the number of each MIS is indicated on top. Italicized numbers show the ages corresponding to each data point.

caption.title: Organic matter and productivity proxy records at Lardos.
caption.p: Paleodepth estimates based on the %P/(B+P) ratio. δ13C values of the surface-dwelling planktonic foraminifera Globigerinoides ruber, the deeper-dwelling planktonic foraminfera Globoconella inflata, and the benthic foraminifera Uvigerina peregrina. The δ13C of the fish otoliths results from the δ13C of the dissolved inorganic carbon in the ambient water (indicated here at different depths by the foraminifera δ13C values) and the δ13C of their diet items. Ultimately, the δ13C of otoliths is a proxy of the metabolic rate of the fish. The totalotal organic carbon (TOC) and total nitrogen (TN) contents reflect productivity, and the Branched Isoprenoid Tetraether (BIT) index reflects the source of the organic matter in the sediment (which increases with terrestrial influx). Grey-shaded areas represent interglacials, whereas white areas are glacials; the number of each MIS is indicated on top. Italicized numbers show the ages corresponding to each data point.

caption.title: Planktonic foraminifera biomass, ostracod and sponge spicule counts at Lardos.
caption.p: Paleodepth estimates based on the %P/(B+P) ratio. Grey-shaded areas represent interglacials, whereas white areas are glacials; the number of each MIS is indicated on top. Italicized numbers show the ages corresponding to each data point.

caption.title: Fitted regression for glacial and interglacial climate cycles with extrapolated fish predictions and 95% confidence intervals.

Paleodepth and modeled lifetime-average depths where the two mesopelagic fish species lived in the study area, obtained from the δ18Ο values in their otoliths by modeling the thermohaline gradient using the δ18Ο values of the different species of foraminifera.
caption.p: The circle diameter scales with otolith weight, reflecting fish size, whereas the vertical lines indicate the depth ranges. Grey-shaded areas represent interglacials, whereas white areas are glacials; the number of each MIS is indicated on top. Italicized numbers show the ages corresponding to each data point.

caption.title: SST time series for: Lardos (this study), Site LC07 (Martínez-Dios et al., 2021), Site U1385 (Rodrigues et al., 2017), ODP Site 975 (Quivelli et al., 2020, 2021), and M.J. Montalbano Jonico (Marino et al., 2020; Peral et al., 2020).
caption.p: The mean SSTs for all the localities are shown in (Agiadi et al., 2024b).
